awd_titl_txt: Arctic Air-Sea Fluxes and the Exchange Through Fram Strait
awd_abstract_narration:
The project will use theoretical and numerical modeling approaches to understand the movement of water, heat, and salt through the Fram Strait connecting the Nordic Seas to the Arctic Ocean. These variables are important because they influence the amount of ice formed in the eastern Arctic Ocean and the amount of water transported from coastal shelves to the ocean basin interior. Ice cover affects the amount of heat put into the atmosphere, atmospheric weather patterns, and private, commercial, and military marine navigation. Water temperature, salinity, and the exchange between the shelves and deep ocean help determine the abundance and species of marine life that can be supported in the region. Thus, understanding processes controlling flow through Fram Strait is of crucial importance for the climate system, the Arctic ecosystem, commercial and local fisheries, shipping, and national security. The investigator will incorporate results from this program into graduate level classes and lectures at the Geophysical Fluid Dynamics Summer School at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution (WHOI) to provide training on numerical methods, applied mathematics, and computer modeling.

This study addresses the fundamental dynamics of the Arctic Ocean general circulation and its connection to lower latitudes. The approach combines a multi-component theoretical model with an idealized but high-resolution eddy resolving coupled ocean/ice general circulation model of the Arctic. The goal is to relate basic quantities -- such as ice cover; freshwater content; air-sea exchange; and heat, freshwater, and mass transport through Fram Strait -- to external forcing due to wind, heat loss, runoff, and variations in Atlantic Water temperature and salinity advected in from the Nordic Seas. In addition to providing dynamical insight into the controlling physics, this approach allows for a simple assessment of how the system is likely to respond to changing environmental parameters and of the existence of multiple equilibria or abrupt transitions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on transports through two of the main gateways to the Arctic Ocean, Fram Strait and Bering Strait. A theory was developed to demonstrate how the mean ice thickness and export from the central Arctic Ocean through Fram St depends on environmental parameters such as atmospheric temperature, Coriolis parameter, and wind stress. In the eastern Arctic the ice is thin and easily blown to the west by the wind. In the western Arctic the ice is thick and moves slowly to the southwest. Predictions from the theory agree well with idealized numerical model simulations. The theory predicts a complicated relationship between ice volume in the Arctic Ocean and atmospheric temperature and wind strength, which are both expected to increase in a warming climate. Increasing temperature always results in less ice but increasing wind initially results in more ice due to build up in the west but eventually there will be less ice as the fast-moving ice regime expands.

The waters flowing through Bering Strait were connected to the recently discovered Chukchi Slope Current through a combined model and data analysis. It was shown that over half of the waters flowing into Barrow Canyon turn to the west and flow along the slope. Some of these waters are mixed offshore by eddies, some flows northward along the Chukchi Borderland to get entrained into the Beaufort Gyre, and some continues westward along the continental slope.

The observed biological "hotspot" in Barrow Canyon was shown to be a result of the flow acceleration as waters are funneled from the broad Chukchi shelf into the narrow Barrow Canyon. Dynamical analysis was used to demonstrate that this acceleration forces a downwelling of nutrients from the base of the halocline to the bottom of the canyon, in close agreement with observations. The theory also predicts that the degree of downwelling is determined by the strength of the flow and the water stratification, in good agreement with the variability in observed chlorophyl distributions.

An idealized model of the Arctic Ocean was used to study the dynamical influences of wind forcing, flow through Bering Strait, mixing, and bottom topography on the circulation across the Arctic and the flow through Fram Strait and the Canadian Arctic Archipelago.  Wind stress is the primary forcing mechanism and this simple model is able to represent the dominant circulation features of the Arctic halocline: the Beaufort Gyre and the Trans Polar Drift. It was shown that the Canadian (western) and Eurasian (eastern) basins of the Arctic are dynamically connected. Also, the flow through Bering Strait influences not only the western Arctic but also the eastern Arctic, and the flow through both Fram Strait and the Canadian Arctic Archipelago. Mean advection, eddy fluxes, and diapycnal mixing are all important in determining the mean circulation and thickness of the halocline.

This grant also contributed to studies related to the transport of benthic nutrients in the Chukchi Sea, boundary current variability around Greenland, wind- and buoyancy-forced exchange across the Greenland-Scotland Ridge, and the mean and variability of currents along the Chukchi shelfbreak and slope.
